review.title: Query Answering with Inconsistent Existential Rules under Stable Model Semantics
review.abstract: Traditional inconsistency-tolerent query answering in ontology-based data access relies on selecting maximal components of an ABox/database which are consistent with the ontology. However, some rules in ontologies might be unreliable if they are extracted from ontology learning or written by unskillful knowledge engineers. In this paper we present a framework of handling inconsistent existential rules under stable model semantics, which is defined by a notion called rule repairs to select maximal components of the existential rules. Surprisingly, for R-acyclic existential rules with R-stratified or guarded existential rules with stratified negations, both the data complexity and combined complexity of query answering under the rule {repair semantics} remain the same as that under the conventional query answering semantics. This leads us to propose several approaches to handle the rule {repair semantics} by calling answer set programming solvers. An experimental evaluation shows that these approaches have good scalability of query answering under rule repairs on realistic cases.

sections.heading: Experimental Evaluation
sections.text: To demonstrate the effectiveness, we have implemented a prototype system for answering queries for R-acyclic rule languages within the scope of rule repair semantics w.r.t. ≤, P, ≤ P and ≤ w by calling a state-of-the-art ASP solver.

sections.heading: From Query Answering to ASP
sections.text: In order to improve efficiency, we use a specific algorithm for each rule repair semantics. The algorithms are all based on the search for the first width. Rule repairs w.r.t. use the basic process described in Alg. 1, and an exponential check is performed during the process. For rule repairs w.r.t. ≤, it works better for the reason that there is no need to search the other levels as soon as it finds uniform sentences. As for rule repairs w.r.t. P., we design an algorithm that iterates over the rules from low to high prioritization. As soon as consistent results are found in the rules with lower prioritization, the search stops. It is known that ≤ P can be translated into ≤ w, but not vice versa. As for ≤ w, we search by deleting rules from the lowest weight to the highest prioritization. Overall, the algorithms for situations with lower prioritization or weighting are much more efficient if the following rule conditions are met: The lower weighted in the rule is weighted in the rule (The lower weighted in the rule).

sections.heading: Experiments
sections.text: We developed a prototype system QAIER1 (Query Answering with Inconsistent Existential Rules) in C + +. QAIER can answer queries with inconsistent R-acyclic rule sets. When it comes to verifying the existence of stable models, QAIER calls an ASP solver that includes clingo-4.4.02.Benchmarks to estimate the performance of QAIER in terms of data complexity, we use the modified LUBM3 table as a benchmark. Since LUBM is not an R-acyclic, we modified LUBM by changing atoms and deleting rules to ensure that modified LUBM rules are R-acyclic. We use HermiT 4 to transform the modified LUBM ontology into DL clauses, and replace at least number constraints in head atoms with existential neglects, then we get 127 rules and we add standard weights or restrictions below.

sections.heading: Related Work and Conclusions
sections.text: With regard to the amendment of the rule set / Tbox for repair, Meyer et al. (2006) have proposed an algorithm running in EXPTIME that finds maximum term-satisfactory terminologies in ALC. Scharrenbach et al. (2010) have shown that probabilistic description logic can be used to resolve conflicts and obtain a unified knowledge base from which to draw conclusions. Qi and Du (2009) have also proposed model-based revision operators for terminology in DL, and Wang et al. (2014) have introduced a model-theoretical approach to revision of ontology. To address uncertainties arising from inconsistency, Gottlob et al. (2013) have expanded the Datalog ± Language with probable uncertainty based on Markov logic networks. More generally, a number of papers have focused on reasoning with inconsistent ontologies, see Huang, van Harmelen and ten references each 2005; al and therein.
